Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: CESER: EAGER: "FabWave" - A Pilot Manufacturing Cyberinfrastructure for Shareable Access to Information Rich Product Manufacturing Data

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Advanced manufacturing research is dependent on access to large datasets of product models to enable product designers to learn from past errors, and to discover and develop new solutions. However, such datasets are typically archived in inaccessible repositories and may be poorly described and difficult to use by others. Current manufacturing research must shift from siloed repositories of product manufacturing data to a federated, decentralized, open and inter-operable approach. This transformation can be achieved by embedding cyber-capability in every physical end-point, be it on a desktop used by a product designer or within the control systems of a manufacturing machine. The goal of this project is to develop a pilot manufacturing-focused cyberinfrastructure called FabWave. FabWave will gather together digital data on product and manufacturing processes from diverse sources, in particular, three-dimensional (3D) computer aided design (CAD) models generated by academia and public community users, into a new rich dataset that, in turn, will be fully accessible to manufacturing researchers and others. FabWave's system design will be driven by the needs of the manufacturing research community, and the project will encourage its adoption by academic users, government labs and the public. FabWave will aim to lower the barriers for users to upload, share and download 3D product model data; it will also enable manufacturing science researchers to gain access to an information rich dataset for testing and evaluation of algorithms to advance manufacturing research and offer the capability for the community to build custom apps that provide services to the community. This infrastructure development project aligns with the NSF Harnessing Data for 21st Century Science and Engineering Big Ideas vision and can serve to improve US competitiveness in advanced manufacturing.

The de novo cyberinfrastructure tools to be built in the FabWave project include: 1) Direct plugins within design software to allow easier capture of metadata and upload of 3D product models to the FabWave repository with limited human interaction; 2) a data-store with application programming interface (API) tools to allow users to write scripts to search through the repository for content specific to their research questions. Innovative use of the Inter-Planetary File System (IPFS) protocols along with next generation unstructured databases will serve to index and enable search services for Fabwave's users. the project will demonstrate use of FabWave for development of community facing third-party apps and libraries. Ultimately, the research community will have access to a rich source of product datasets created within research laboratories, within classes and through other open sourced projects. This data network, if expanded across universities, would accelerate advancements in cybermanufacturing, engineering systems design, and cyber-physical systems in manufacturing. In addition, FabWave will enable new areas of research in manufacturing information integration and informatics combined with reducing the barriers to exploring the science of manufacturing machine intelligence. This award is supported by the Division of Civil, Mechanical and Manufacturing Innovation and the Office of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project is to plan and develop a pilot manufacturing focused cyberinfrastructure called FabWave (FW) that will serve to integrate digital product data, in the form of 3D Computer Aided Design (CAD) models generated by academia and public community users. FabWave?s system design will be driven by the needs of the manufacturing research community with the aim to be adopted by a number of academic users, government labs and the public. 

App plugins were written for Autodesk Fusion 360 and SolidWorks design software. These two design software packages are commonly used by the academic community in generating student led design and manufacturing projects. These plugins were tested in courses offered at NC State and USC, through the digital manufacturing and additive manufacturing courses. A campus computing infrastructure was developed to collect data, store raw data and data processed to capture its meta-data and the various file formats that are useful to the engineering community.

Another app plugin was developed for fused deposition modeling (FDM) 3D printers. The FDM process is the most widely used additive manufacturing process and the students all around the nation are extensively using FDM printers in their design and manufacturing projects. A campus computing infrastructure was developed to collect digital and physical manufacturing data of such an additive manufacturing process to capture its meta-data and the various file formats that are useful to the engineering community.

A particular challenge that this project faced is that when a lot of product data is generating, searching for product models is hard, particularly because we cannot rely on text keywords to search for product model data. Enabling search on 3D data is critical to making such datasets accessible. Another challenge was that the models was not classified and finding a category for each model was hard. These challenges were solved by the research team in creating a geometric deep learning algorithm that can help auto-cluster similar shapes into a group dataset category. These clusters can then be manually labelled by humans for enabling search modalities. These human labelled clusters also become training data as new models are captured.

Data generated from this project have been requested and downloaded from around the world. Users who have accessed our design datasets has varied from users wanting the data from augmented/virtual reality applications and Artificial Intelligence with Product Models.

Besides NC State and USC, new partnerships were initiated with academia, government labs and industry partners. These include New York University, National Institute of Standards and Technology, Autodesk (AI Team) and Stratasys (GrabCAD Community). This project laid down the foundations for a manufacturing cyber infrastructure which will in the future lead to efforts in further developing and deploying a national cyberinfrastructure initiative linking data from multiple universities.

 


Last Modified: 11/08/2020
Modified by: Yong Chen

Images (1 of )
  • A manufacturing cyberinfrastructure called ?FabWave? is being built to create an information-rich, continuously developing database of digital data generated from product lifecycle to facilitate advanced manufacturing research.
    Yang Xu, Yong Chen, Binil Starly
    Yong Chen
    Stacked layer software architecture of FabWave
  • To gather 3D mechanical CAD models and associated meta-data, plug-ins were developed for two CAD software � SolidWorks and Autodesk Fusion 360, using their API to enable users to upload their data to the FabWave repository with ease.
    Yang Xu, Yong Chen, Binil Starly
    Copyrighted
    Yong Chen
    Developed plug-in modules for SolidWorks and Autodesk Fusion 360 to collect CAD data
  • In order to spur innovations in smart manufacturing research, we integrated many forms of manufacturing data to the FabWave repository besides CAD data. We divided the additive manufacturing process data into digital manufacturing data and physical manufacturing process data in FabWave.
    Yang Xu, Yong Chen, Binil Starly
    Copyrighted
    Yong Chen
    The manufacturing data acquisition system of 3D printers
  • The data-driven smart manufacturing researches depend on large amounts of classified and categorized data to help improve results. A data acquisition system for fused deposition modeling 3D printers was developed for FabWave.
    Yang Xu, Yong Chen, Binil Starly
    Copyrighted
    Yong Chen
    Relation of data acquisition system with the data-driven additive manufacturing research
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The goal of this project is to plan and develop a pilot manufacturing focused cyberinfrastructure called FabWave (FW) that will serve to integrate digital product data, in the form of 3D Computer Aided Design (CAD) models generated by academia and public community users. FabWave?s system design will be driven by the needs of the manufacturing research community with the aim to be adopted by a number of academic users, government labs and the public. App plugins were written for Autodesk Fusion 360 and SolidWorks design software. These two design software packages are commonly used by the academic community in generating student led design and manufacturing projects. These plugins were tested in courses offered at NC State and USC, through the digital manufacturing and additive manufacturing courses. A campus computing infrastructure was developed to collect data, store raw data and data processed to capture its meta-data and the various file formats that are useful to the engineering community. Another app plugin was developed for fused deposition modeling (FDM) 3D printers. The FDM process is the most widely used additive manufacturing process and the students all around the nation are extensively using FDM printers in their design and manufacturing projects. A campus computing infrastructure was developed to collect digital and physical manufacturing data of such an additive manufacturing process to capture its meta-data and the various file formats that are useful to the engineering community. A particular challenge that this project faced is that when a lot of product data is generating, searching for product models is hard, particularly because we cannot rely on text keywords to search for product model data. Enabling search on 3D data is critical to making such datasets accessible. Another challenge was that the models was not classified and finding a category for each model was hard. These challenges were solved by the research team in creating a geometric deep learning algorithm that can help auto-cluster similar shapes into a group dataset category. These clusters can then be manually labelled by humans for enabling search modalities. These human labelled clusters also become training data as new models are captured. Data generated from this project have been requested and downloaded from around the world. Users who have accessed our design datasets has varied from users wanting the data from augmented/virtual reality applications and Artificial Intelligence with Product Models. Besides NC State and USC, new partnerships were initiated with academia, government labs and industry partners. These include New York University, National Institute of Standards and Technology, Autodesk (AI Team) and Stratasys (GrabCAD Community). This project laid down the foundations for a manufacturing cyber infrastructure which will in the future lead to efforts in further developing and deploying a national cyberinfrastructure initiative linking data from multiple universities.
